content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a really hard time sleeping lately. Work has been super stressful, and I can't seem to stop my thoughts from racing at night. My partner suggested I try talking to someone about it, but honestly, I’m not sure how much it’ll help.

Thank you for sharing that—your lack of sleep and work stress sound really overwhelming. It must be tough when your mind doesn’t seem to quiet down, even when you’re trying to rest. What are your thoughts on how this has been affecting you lately?

It's been affecting me a lot, honestly. I wake up feeling exhausted, and it’s hard to focus at work, which just makes me more worried about my performance. I feel like I'm stuck in this cycle, and I don’t know how to break out of it.

It sounds frustrating to feel caught in a cycle where poor sleep leads to exhaustion, which then makes work even harder and adds to your stress. You’re clearly aware of how this is impacting different parts of your life, and that awareness is a great first step. What do you think might help you work toward breaking out of this cycle?

I honestly don’t know. I’ve tried going to bed earlier or listening to calming music, but my mind just constantly races with “what ifs” about work and finances. No matter what I do, I can't seem to shut it off, and that makes me feel even more stuck.

You’ve been trying different things to help yourself, but those racing thoughts about work and finances keep coming back, making it feel like there’s no escape. That’s a heavy burden to carry, especially when it feels like nothing is working. What helped you decide to try those strategies, like going to bed earlier or calming music?

I just wanted to do something to help. I figured if I could relax more or get extra rest, maybe it would make a difference, but it hasn’t really helped much. I think I just feel this pressure all the time—like I can’t afford to fail, for my family’s sake—and it’s hard to let go of that.

It sounds like you’re carrying a lot of pressure and responsibility on your shoulders, and you’ve been doing your best to find relief, even when it hasn’t quite worked so far. That determination to try something for yourself really shows how much you care, not just for yourself but for your family. What would you want things to look like if that pressure felt more manageable?

If that pressure felt more manageable, I guess I’d feel more present—for my family, for myself. Maybe I wouldn’t feel so on edge all the time, and I could actually enjoy moments with them instead of constantly worrying. It’s like I don’t even know what relaxing feels like anymore.

It sounds like being present and truly enjoying time with your family is something you really value, but that constant worry has made feeling relaxed and connected almost impossible. You’ve imagined what life could be like if the pressure eased, which shows a lot of insight. What do you think would make it possible for you to take small steps toward that kind of peace?

If that pressure felt more manageable, I guess I’d feel more present—for my family, for myself. Maybe I wouldn’t feel so on edge all the time, and I could actually enjoy moments with them instead of constantly worrying. It’s like I don’t even know what relaxing feels like anymore.

Not knowing what relaxation feels like anymore must make everything feel even harder to handle. You're holding onto this hope to be more present and at peace, especially for moments with your family. That hope is really important. Would it be helpful to explore any areas of your routine or habits that could support a small step toward the kind of calmness you’re longing for?

Not knowing what relaxing feels like anymore must feel isolating and exhausting. Wanting to be more present for your family shows how much they mean to you, even while you’re under this stress. Have you ever had moments—even small ones—that felt peaceful or less overwhelming in recent weeks?
Yes, there were some moments when I felt peaceful. Walking with my family recently helped me relax a little.

That’s really good to hear. It sounds like spending time walking with your family gave you even just a small break from all the stress you’ve been feeling. What do you think it was about that time together that helped you feel a bit more at ease?
I think it was being outside and focusing on my family instead of work. Just moving and being in the fresh air helped me shift my thoughts a little.
It also felt good to see my kids laughing and enjoying themselves. It reminded me of what I'm working hard for, and for a moment, I wasn't stuck in my own head.

It sounds like seeing your kids happy and laughing really brought you back to what matters most—those meaningful moments with them. That connection seemed to give you a break from the worries that are so hard to escape and reminded you of your bigger purpose. How do you feel about exploring ways to create more moments like that?
I’d like that, but I’m just not sure how to make it happen with everything going on. It feels hard to make time when my head is constantly spinning with stress.

It's understandable to feel unsure about where to start when stress feels nonstop and time feels limited. Even though that weight is heavy, the fact that you're open to finding ways to create more of those meaningful moments is really important. What do you think would feel manageable—a small step you could take toward experiences like the walk with your family?
